body: I would really appreciate this. I'm confused about the parameters and which component (client/server) uses which backend/store.

rename.from: [DOC-FIX] Show diagrams and elaborate interaction between the client and the tracking server
rename.to: [FR] Show diagrams and elaborate interaction between the client and the tracking server

rename.from: [FR] Show diagrams and elaborate interaction between the client and the tracking server
rename.to: [FR] Show diagrams and elaborate on interaction between the client and the tracking server

body: @marcraminv Thanks for the picture, it's a good start. Will try to break it up and modularize for different scenarios, and will try use our standard icons so we have consistency across our figures in the docs. Thanks for the good start, and will share the pictures with you here!

@Minyus Thanks for the illustrative diagram. A couple of things:

1. You might want to distinguish between a local instance and a remote instance of the tracking server. 
2. For local instance, the client directly interacts with the local FileStore (`file:/path/mlruns`) and local backend store if set with `sqlite:///mlruns.db`
3. For remote instance, running at port XXXX, the client interacts with the tracking server via REST API. The remote tracking server interacts with the backend store and artifact store when launched with ---backend-store-uri and --default_root_artifact, including the NFS mounted FS. (The client writes directly to the mounted FS since artifacts may be large.)
4. The dashed box with "Backend Store" and "Artifact Store" is a bit misleading; they suggest a separate process.

In its simplest form, a local tracking server:

![mlflow-tracking-module](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1117597/101093893-60b4c100-3570-11eb-953a-2f0350037f89.png)

In its simplest form, a remote-tracking server:

![mlflow-tracking-module](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1117597/101094048-a3769900-3570-11eb-86b7-d146c21fa67f.png)
@dmatrix are this pics available in the documentation? they look really cool! Kudos for that 👍

Hi @dmatrix 

Thank you for sharing the diagrams.

First, data files are uploaded to and downloaded from the artifact storage directly (mentioned at https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/2834), so the diagram named "MLflow Tracking Server" is a bit inaccurate.

Second, the database (PostgreSQL, MySQL, MS SQL) can be accessed through APIs (e.g. REST API, CLI, Python) directly without using MLflow Tracking Server although MLflow Tracking server is still need to use the Web UI.
This way, the models registered in the Model Registry can be deployed through the APIs even if MLflow Tracking server is down. So, I'd suggest to add the diagram for this more robust setup like this:

![image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Minyus/Tools_for_ML_Lifecycle_Management/main/mlflow/mlflow_architecture.png)
[Original SVG file](https://github.com/Minyus/Tools_for_ML_Lifecycle_Management/blob/main/mlflow/mlflow_architecture.drawio.svg)

@Minyus [here are scenarios and workflows](https://github.com/dmatrix/mlflow-tests/tree/master/py/mlflow/server) of how clients and tracking server in MLflow interact with respective backend and artifact stores, based on default and/or supplied arguments while launching the tracking server. I have reviewed this with the team.

Use these scenarios as a way to understand how each component interacts with which instance of the backend and artifact store and the respective component code responsible for it. 

Admittedly,  these workflows have been a source of confusion among users, especially when clients interact with remote cloud storage to upload artifacts where authentication credentials are required. We are working on improving these workflows so that the artifacts are easily proxied via the tracking server (read some discussion in #629 ).

After a review, we'll add these scenarios as part of the documentation.
